titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William Silver Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Mary Caldera and staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 11:21

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers document William Silver's personal life, seminary thesis, his application for ordination into the United Presbyterian Church, and his later life in the Cherry Grove community on Fire Island, New York. Particularly well documented is Silver's coming out process and the Presbyterian Church's debate on the ordination of homosexuals in the 1970s. The papers consist of journals, writings, sermons, correspondence, photographs, newsletters, news clippings, and printed material.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Estate of William Silver, 2007, 2008, and 2011.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: William Silver Papers (MS 1897). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: The papers include images in digital formats. Further description of file formats provided in Collection Contents.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: William Silver, who was also known as Violet, was born September 8, 1947, in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. He received a Bachelor of Arts (1969) from Ohio Wesleyan University, majoring in Fine Arts and Pre-theology. He received a Masters of Divinity from the Union Theological Seminary in 1973. In his final year at Seminary, Silver came out as a gay man and based his thesis project on his coming out process, or "experience of liberation." The project consisted of a series of paintings and a journal where he documented his coming out process.

In 1975 Silver requested ordination in the Presbytery of New York. His request sparked a two year, church-wide debate on the ordination of gay men in the Presbyterian Church. The General Assembly of United Presbyterian Church in the United States adopted a policy that barred self-affirming, practicing gay men from ordination in 1978. The policy, while blocking ordination, allowed for accepting homosexuals into the church and even ordaining repentant homosexuals who led a celibate or heterosexual life-style. Additionally, the policy protected gay men who were ordained prior to 1978 from being removed from the ministry. Silver continued his involvement with the church as a layman until the 1980s.

He worked as a graphic artist and events organizer. He was a long-time resident and active member of the Cherry Grove, Fire Island (New York) community. He was known for his "High Purple Tea" events and as the publisher of the monthly "Violet's Wild Cherry" events guide. Silver died of complications due to AIDS in 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers document William Silver's personal life, seminary thesis, his application for ordination into the United Presbyterian Church, and his later life in the Cherry Grove community on Fire Island, New York. Particularly well documented is Silver's coming out process and the Presbyterian Church's debate on the ordination of homosexuals in the 1970s. The papers consist of journals, writings, sermons, correspondence, photographs, newsletters, news clippings, and printed material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged by accession.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Formats include: 7 Adobe Photoshop files, 30 Binary Interchange File Format (BIFF) Workbook files, 9 Encapsulated PostScript File Format files, 212 Exchangeable Image File Format files, 4 IBM DisplayWrite Document files, 122 JPEG File Interchange Format files, 2 Text files, 29 Quark Xpress Data files, 80 Tagged Image File Format files, 66 Windows Bitmap files, 1 Windows Executable file, 1 Zip Format file.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Contact Public Services (phone: 203 432-1735, e-mail: mssa.reference@yale.edu) for information on accessing this digital object.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The addition is arranged chronologically within four sections: Personal Writings and Memorabilia, Presbyterian Files, Photographs and Drawings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The addition to the William Silver papers consists of photographs, slides and negatives; Gay Presbyterian-related materials; personal and business correspondence; drawings, childhood and academic materials; and materials related to Fire Island events.

did.unittitle: Correspondence to parents with notes and diary

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes baby book, baptismal certificate, 4-H Club material, high school diploma, and graduation invitation and program.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes report cards, PSAT and SAT scores, junior class play script and program, and scholarship certificates.

did.unittitle: Boy Scouts of America ephemera and memorabilia

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes postcards, brochure, menu, badges and book mark from Philmont Scout Ranch, Cimarron, NM.

did.unittitle: Ohio Wesleyan University event ephemera (mainly flyers)

odd.head: General
odd.p: Contains scholarship award certificates (including Phi Beta Kappa), Union Theological Seminary transcript, and undergraduate and graduate student identification, grade cards, commencement programs and diplomas.

did.unittitle: "Field Work and Social Welfare," class report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Items include business cards, employee identification, and Montour wooden rings.
